position.marginalia_text: Excellentissimo, nemo Satis excellens. Julianus Ca[e]sar, Antica[e]sar.

marginalia.translation: No one is as excellent as the most excellent. Julianus Caesar, the Anti-Caesar.

position.marginalia_text: { Nel mondo mutabile, e leggiero, Costansa è, spesso il variar pensiero. Canto 5. del Tasso.

marginalia.translation: "In this changing and mutable world, Constancy often comes from changing one's mind." The fifth canto of Tasso.

Macchiauelli, piu respettiuo, e ciuile: Aretino piu impetuoso, e fantastico. Quello quasi sempre politico: questo quasi tutto Capriccioso. { Eccoti il Domator d'ogni gagliardo: come dice Tasso del brauo Rinaldo. Chi fù, ch'ardi cotanto, e tanto fece?

marginalia.translation: Words that cause laughter are either stupid, insulting, or loving. In the prologue to Machiaveli's Clizia, there are words full of these three qualities; that is, words which are stupid, insulting, and loving, all full of laughter. But Machiavelli, by not including stupid or insulting characters in his comedy, was required to make use only of loving ones. In the comedies of Pietro Aretino, often there are stupid and insulting characters, and why not? Machiavelli is more respectful and civil, Aretino is more impetuous and fantastical. The former is almost always political, while the latter is almost completely whimsical. Here then is the trainer of every healthy man. As Tasso says of brave Rinaldo: "Who was is that dared so much and so much accomplished?"
In hardship, he laughs at the children of Amphitryon.

position.marginalia_text: Grata breuitas: nouitas: varietas. Singula celerrima: omnia fluentissima. Vnicus mundi adamantinus Stylus. Maximè viuidus, et exquisitus.

marginalia.translation: Agreeable brevity, variety, novelty. Individual things most swift, all things most fluid. The sole adamantine style in the world. Most lively and excellent.

position.marginalia_text: O[e]conomus Aristotelis, et Xenophontis: Politicus Aristotelis, et Bodini. Pragmaticus Taciti, et Speculatoris: stratagematicus Gandini, et Polya[e]ni: secretarius Weccheri, Baconis, omniumq[ue] polyda[e]dalorum: vnicus mundi polytechnus, et polymechanus. Nec ullus in Orbe panergus, tam energus. Semper ad apicem operis, at negotij. |

marginalia.translation: The Economics of Aristotle and Xenophon; the Politics of Aristotle and Bodin. The Pragmatics of Tacitus and Guillaume Durand; the Stratagems of Gandino and Polyaenus. The Secretary of Wecker and Bacon and of every multi-skilled inventor. The only polytechnic and polymechanic in the world. In the world there is no supplement like work. Always at the top of works and activities.
